channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [AMQP-469] Thread safety of ErlangTemplate
item.description:
ErlangTemplate.executeErlangRpc is not threadsafe when used with SingleConnectionFactory.

The code in ErlangTemplate.executeErlangRpc first calls connection.sendRPC then calls connection.receiveRPC(). When used with the SingleConnectionFactory this means that another thread could also be using the same connection.

The end result of this is that connection.sendRPC and connection.receiveRPC() requests become interleaved.

I believe, but have not checked, that with SimpleConnectionFactory, this would not happen as each thread would have its own connection.

I understand that thread safety is not documented, so should be not assumed, so I am issuing this bug mainly to request documentation on the thread safety of the ErlangTemplate.

If ErlangTemplate is intended to be thread safe, this bug should be raised to "Critical".

Yes OtpSelf is threadsafe. The issue is in the usage of the RPC calls in ErlangTemplate:

ErlangTemplate.java

 
public OtpErlangObject executeErlangRpc(final String module, final String function, final OtpErlangList args) {
 
    return execute(new ConnectionCallback<OtpErlangObject>() {
 
        public OtpErlangObject doInConnection(Connection connection) throws Exception {
 
            logger.debug("Sending RPC for module [" + module + "] function [" + function + "] args [" + args);
 
            connection.sendRPC(module, function, args);
 
            //TODO consider dedicated response object.
 
            OtpErlangObject response = connection.receiveRPC();
 
            logger.debug("Response received = " + response.toString());
 
            handleResponseError(module, function, response);
 
            return response;
 
        }
 
    });
 
}

So the call to connection.sendRPC is blocking and the call to connection.receiveRPC() is also blocking. The issue is that another thread can call either of those methods on the same connection and the method calls become interleaved, as there is no synchronization in execute.

I believe the comment in the code "TODO consider dedicated response object." might be significant.

I will try and come up with a test case, but due to the nature of the issue (thread safety), this might be a little tricky.

Well, I have to confirm that we have a thread safety issue. Here is a test-case to reproduce:

@Test                                                                                             
public void testConcurrency() throws Exception {                                                  
	String selfNodeName = "test-node";                                                            
	String peerNodeName = "rabbit@BILAN_WORK";                                                    
                                                                                                  
	SingleConnectionFactory cf = new SingleConnectionFactory(selfNodeName, peerNodeName);         
	cf.afterPropertiesSet();                                                                      
	final ErlangTemplate template = new ErlangTemplate(cf);                                       
	template.afterPropertiesSet();                                                                
                                                                                                  
	ExecutorService executorService = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(10);                           
                                                                                                  
	for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {                                                                
		final int j = i;                                                                          
		executorService.execute(new Runnable() {                                                  
                                                                                                  
			@Override                                                                             
			public void run() {                                                                   
				Assert.assertEquals((long) j, template.executeAndConvertRpc("erlang", "abs", -j));
 
			}                                                                                     
                                                                                                  
		});                                                                                       
	}                                                                                             
                                                                                                  
	executorService.shutdown();                                                                   
                                                                                                  
	assertTrue(executorService.awaitTermination(10, TimeUnit.SECONDS));                           
                                                                                                  
	cf.destroy();                                                                                 
}

The assertEquals doesn't pass for all calls.

Sad.

I think we don't have choice, unless document that SingleConnectionFactory isn't threadsafe.

Will take care soon.

Thank you one more time!

Well, that's true. I did a simple test:

OtpSelf self = new OtpSelf("rabbit-monitor");
 
String hostName = "rabbit@BILAN_WORK";
 
OtpPeer peer = new OtpPeer(hostName);
 
connection = self.connect(peer);

Boris, we had had some internal discussion and decided to get rid of this Erlang support at all.
The RabbitMQ provides RESTfull API for such operations: http://hg.rabbitmq.com/rabbitmq-management/raw-file/rabbitmq_v3_4_3/priv/www/api/index.html.

More info is here: https://www.rabbitmq.com/management.html

Let us know if it is appropriate for your case.
Yes, you may need to override your application to get deal with that HTTP API, but right now it is only a way to overcome your requirements for multy-threaded environment.

In the future we may consider to implement some Java API over that RabbitMQ REST API.

Thanks anyway

Artem, thanks for the update!

I think you're probably right, it seems that the Java <-> Erlang interaction is not as simple as all that.

Using the REST API seems like a vaild solution, and it would certainly work for our use case - we only need to delare bindings dynamically.

We use AmqpAdmin to do the rest of the heavy lifting, as this is a much nicer API than the Erlang stuff. The issue we were solving was that there does not seem to be a method for listing bindings via AmqpAdmin, which leads me into my next question:

Is it possible to get information using com.rabbitmq.client.Channel? It looks like the methods currently defined only declare exchanges/bindings/queues.

Well, one of good advantages of AMQP protocol that is is enough tolerant to the end application. You always can invoke the same queueBind several times without checking if it exists. It is idempotent operation. So, I think your case can be simplified a bit: just get rid of that if binding doesn't exist code and always call queueBind.

Otherwise no: there is no Java API to list bindings. Only that HTTP API.
